SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: George Rocklington
Address: 1022 Temperance St, Saskatoon
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? Humboldt District, Foam Lake
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 20 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? Sacks 98 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Around $2.50
How much did you use graham flour? Flours
Whole wheat flour? Ground flour
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Don't remember
What other grain products did you use? ........................................
Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? Yes Farina? ........................................
Other? ........................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Coffee grinder

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail to us. Your answers will be preserved as part of the Provincial Archives of Saskatchewan.

Name: George Pocklington
Address: 1222 Temperance Street, Saskatoon, Sask.
Date: 1954

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1896
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Northend District, Yarrow Lake
   Where had you been living before that? England
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
   How far was it to your nearest store? 80 miles
   How often would a visit be made to the store? Occasionally
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Regal, Hardtack
   In what quantities did you buy it? 10 lbs
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
   How much did you use graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour? Yes
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 35¢
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes
   Other? No
   Did you grind your own wheat for pancakes? Yes
   How did you grind it? With a grinder

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

butter? bought at first

eggs? had it here at first

Did you make butter? yes

Did you make cheese? no

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Fish and rabbits

How did you get fresh meat? Home fresh season

How often did you get fresh meat? every season

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? no

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? wild game

What kinds? Chilly prairie

chicken after we bought a gun

For how long? Years

What part did fish play in the family diet? Always

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Both

Kinds? Jack fish

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

On Homestead 1906 to 1912

Breakfast: - porridge, bread & butter & jam
Dinner: - fish or rabbit potatoes when we had them and pudding of many kinds
Supper what was left from dinner or eggs sometimes and tea. Children age 4 and 7 years.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ....... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Just another meal and day.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Often very short
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate number of people or guests.

On Remembrance Day 1912

Breakfast - porridge - boiled a bit of jam
Dinner - fish or mutton pot pie when we had them
and pudding of many kinds
Supper which was off from dinner on dry occasions
and tea. Children age 4 and 7 years.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Just another meal and day.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Often very short
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Didn't have much in the early days. No chance to make a meal so now there is a vast difference.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

When husband earned a little money threshing money was spent in bulk groceries from Hudson's Bay Store at Fort St. John.
21. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Didn't have much in the early days. No need to make a meal. No oven thus is a vast difference.

22. Then did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

When hard times came I lost money at trading.

Money was spent on bulk growing or from Hudson's Bay Store and Hudson's.
